advice.advice: If at first you don’t succeed, call it version 1.0.
Programmers are tools for converting caffeine into code.
Why do programmers prefer dark mode? Because light attracts bugs.
Never trust a computer you can’t throw out a window.
To err is human; to really mess things up, you need a computer.
There are two hard things in computer science: cache invalidation and naming things. The third is off-by-one errors.
A good programmer is someone who looks both ways before crossing a one-way street.
If debugging is the process of removing bugs, then programming must be the process of putting them in.
Why do programmers hate nature? It has too many bugs.
In programming, the hardest thing to do is to keep your code from being hacked while simultaneously making it accessible to everyone. It’s like walking a tightrope over a pit of alligators.
Don’t worry if it doesn’t work right. If everything did, you’d be out of a job.
A programmer’s favorite type of music is ‘Bandwith.’
You know you’re a programmer when you spend more time trying to figure out why your code isn’t working than actually writing the code.
Programmers are the only people who can work in a code dungeon and still manage to find a sunny spot in their day.
A good programmer will always tell you that their code is ‘almost perfect’ and never ‘perfect.’
Keep calm and code on. If it’s broken, there’s a solution — or at least a workaround!
If you can’t convince them, confuse them. But only if you’re confident your code will work eventually.
Code like there’s no tomorrow — and then clean up the mess when you wake up.
If you think you’re done with a project, just remember: it’s never really done. It’s just in a perpetual state of ‘almost there.’
Remember, code doesn’t lie, but comments do. Always keep an eye on your comments — they might be plotting against you.
